A collection of free, open-source tools and resources I've found useful over the years. Some I've worked through extensively, others I'm still exploring. If it's here, it's worth your time.

## Machine Learning & Deep Learning

[Deep Learning with R for Beginners](https://github.com/TrainingByPackt/Deep-Learning-with-R-for-Beginners) – Hands-on introduction to deep learning using R.

[Neural Networks and Deep Learning](http://neuralnetworksanddeeplearning.com/index.html) – Free online book that builds intuition from the ground up.

[But what is a neural network?](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l-9ALe3U-Fg) – Honestly the best and most intuitive explanation of how neural networks work I've heard. 

[Towards Data Science](https://towardsdatascience.com/) – Fantastic blog covering a broad range of topics in data science and ML.

[Deep Learning with R (2nd Edition)](https://livebook.manning.com/book/deep-learning-with-r-second-edition/chapter-1) – A very underrated book that's well-written and accessible. Free to read at this link.

[Machine Learning A-Z: Tips and Resources](https://datamastersclub.com/machine-learning-a-z-tips-and-resources/) – Curated collection of ML learning materials.

---

## Blogs & Portfolios Worth Following

[Tom Jenkins](https://tomjenkins.netlify.app/) – Clean portfolio with solid bioinformatics content.

[Dave Tang's Blog](https://davetang.org/muse/) – Long-running blog with practical bioinformatics tutorials and musings.

[David Goodsell's Molecular Illustrations](https://ccsb.scripps.edu/goodsell/) – Making science come alive with art. An utter inspiration.

[Diving into Genetics and Genomics](https://divingintogeneticsandgenomics.com/) – I've been following Tommy for over seven years—he was one of the first bioinformaticians I found online. Produces an insane amount of content on a wide range of topics.

---

## Programming & Bioinformatics

[SIB Swiss Institute of Bioinformatics Training Materials](https://www.sib.swiss/training/training-materials) – High-quality courses and tutorials.

[LibreTexts: Computational Biology](https://bio.libretexts.org/Bookshelves/Computational_Biology) – Free textbook covering core concepts.

[Bioinformatics Workbook](https://bioinformaticsworkbook.org/#gsc.tab=0) – Comprehensive resource covering data analysis workflows.

[Computational Genomics with R](https://compgenomr.github.io/book/) – Builds from basic biology through to multi-omics. Excellent progression.

[Coddy](https://coddy.tech/) – Interactive coding tutorials.

[Automate the Boring Stuff with Python](https://automatetheboringstuff.com/) – A popular book that makes learning Python feel useful and practical. Free to read online.

[Rosalind](https://rosalind.info/problems/locations/) – Practice problems for brushing up on bioinformatics and programming concepts.

[Hands-On Programming with R](https://rstudio-education.github.io/hopr/) – Nice introduction to R.

[Hadley Wickham](https://hadley.nz/) – The legend of the tidyverse. Books available free online, including:
  - [Tidy Modeling with R](https://www.tmwr.org/)

[MIT Computational Biology Course Materials](https://compbio.mit.edu/teaching.html) – Free MIT course content in computational biology taught by Manolis Kellis.

---

## Grapevine Resources

A little niche—for those looking for up-to-date community tools.

[Grapedia](https://grapedia.org/) – Comprehensive grapevine genomics and genetics database.

---

## Useful Tools & Repositories

[Our World in Data](https://ourworldindata.org/) – Research and data on global challenges. Invaluable for context.

[csvtk](https://github.com/shenwei356/csvtk) – Command-line toolkit for working with CSV files.

[BioNumbers](https://book.bionumbers.org/) – The cell biology by the numbers book. Fascinating reference.

[Friends Don't Let Friends Make Bad Graphs](https://github.com/cxli233/FriendsDontLetFriends) – A guide to data visualisation best practices.

[Academic Workflow: Zotero + Obsidian](https://medium.com/@alexandraphelan/an-updated-academic-workflow-zotero-obsidian-cffef080addd) – This post became my key guide for setting up a writing system I now can't imagine functioning without. The ideal organisational backbone for research and writing.

[PLOS Ten Simple Rules Collection](https://collections.plos.org/collection/ten-simple-rules/) – A surprisingly helpful and practical collection of tips for academics.

[Sticky by YesChat AI](https://www.yeschat.ai/gpts-9t557WCZP3m-Sticky) – In case your drawing skills don't extend to stick figures.

---

## AI Tools for Literature Management

[Research Rabbit](https://app.researchrabbit.ai/?auth-open=sign-in) – Visual citation networks and paper discovery.

[Anara AI](https://anara.com/) – AI-powered literature review assistant.

[SciSpace](https://scispace.com/) – Simplifies reading and understanding research papers.

[NotebookLM](https://notebooklm.google/) – Google's AI notebook for synthesising research.

[Consensus](https://consensus.app/) - AI-powered search engine

There are honestly too many of these now, but these are the ones I've found useful in "free" tier for gathering, organising and querying papers.

---

## Because It's Important to Have Hobbies

[Marty Music](https://www.martymusic.com/) – Guitar tutorials for absolute beginners.

[JustinGuitar](https://www.justinguitar.com/) – Structured, free guitar course.

[Drawabox](https://drawabox.com/lessons) – Learn to draw through deliberate practice.

[Free Learning List](https://freelearninglist.org/) – Massive collection of free online courses across all subjects.
